questions.text: During a cholecystectomy, the surgical resident accidentally jabbed a sharp instrument into the area immediately posterior to the epiploic foramen, resulting in severe bleeding. Which vessel was most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The inferior vena cava lies immediately posterior to the epiploic foramen and is likely to be injured in this case.

Epiploic foramen:

Also known as the Foramen of Winslow/omental foramen, it is a passageway between the greater peritoneal sac and the lesser peritoneal sac.

Boundaries:

  • Superiorly - caudate lobe of the liver
  • Inferiorly - the first part of the duodenum
  • Anteriorly - right free margin of lesser omentum (hepatoduodenal part)
  • Posteriorly - inferior vena cava

Explanation of other options:

Aorta (Option A): The aorta lies next to the inferior vena cava, but is a little more to the left and a little deeper - it does not lie immediately posterior to the epiploic foramen.

Portal vein (Option C): The Portal vein lies anterior to the epiploic foramen in the right free margin of the lesser omentum.

Right renal artery (Option D): The right renal artery is a branch of the aorta. Like the aorta, it is too deep to be a vessel immediately behind the foramen.

choices.text: Gallbladder fossa and the round ligament of the liver
Gallbladder fossa and inferior vena cava
Falciform ligament and right hepatic vein

questions.text: The division between the true right and left lobes (internal lobes) of the liver may be visualised on the outside of the liver as a plane passing through the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The line joining the inferior vena cava groove and gall bladder fossa divides the liver into right and left functional lobes. This line is called the Cantles' line.

Segmental anatomy of the liver:

The liver is anatomically divided into right and left lobes by the falciform ligament.

The liver is functionally divided into segments by 3 major and 3 minor fissures.

The current understanding of the functional anatomy of the liver is based on Couinaud's division of the liver into eight functional segments based on the distribution of portal venous branches in the parenchyma.

The liver is divided into four portal sectors (right anterior, right posterior, left medial and left lateral) by the four main branches of the hepatic portal vein. The three main hepatic veins lie between these sectors as intersectoral veins. Each sector is subdivided into segments (usually two).

Major fissures:

  • Cantle's line: This line is drawn from the IVC groove to the fossa of the gall bladder. Cantle's line divides the liver into right and left true or functional lobes.
  • Left portal fissure (Falciform ligament): The left fissure subdivides the functional left lobe into lateral and medial segments.
  • Right portal fissure: The right fissure subdivides the functional right lobe into anterior and posterior segments.

Minor fissures:

Venous Fissure: The fissure contains ligamentum venosum. Ligamentum venosum is the remnant of the ductus venosus.

Umbilical fissure: Contains ligamentum teres, which is the remnant of the left umbilical vein.

Ganz fissure: This is the fissure over the fossa of the gallbladder. It is used in laparoscopic cholecystectomy to differentiate between the cystic bile duct (above the sulcus) and the common bile duct (below the sulcus).

choices.text: Common hepatic duct, liver and cystic duct
Cystic duct, right hepatic artery and right hepatic duct
Gall bladder, liver and common bile duct
Left hepatic duct, liver and cystic duct

questions.text: You are observing a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. As the surgeon prepares to ligate the cystic artery, he asks where to locate and you respond to it as in Calot's triangle. Which anatomical structures help identify this triangle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Calot's triangle is an isosceles triangle based on the common hepatic duct, liver and cystic duct, forming its sides and containing the cystic artery.

Calot's triangle:

Boundaries:

Superior - inferior surface of the liver

Inferiorly - cystic duct

Medially - common hepatic duct

Contents:

  • Cystic artery (usually a branch of the hepatic artery)
  • Right hepatic artery
  • Cystic lymph node

questions.text: During the endoscopic evaluation of a 65-year-old man with a history of chronic duodenal ulcer, the ulcer was found eroding the posterior wall of the first part of the duodenum. If the ulcer perforates, which of the following structures is least likely to be affected by the acidic gastric contents?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The pancreas lies inferior to the first part of the duodenum, and the main pancreatic duct is found deep within the pancreas. Thus, it is not likely to be damaged by the duodenal ulcer.

  • The first part of the duodenum (superior part) lies anterior to the gastroduodenal artery, bile duct and hepatic portal vein and anterosuperior to the head and neck of the pancreas. (Option A, C, D)
  • The gastroduodenal artery lies immediately posterior to the posterior wall of the duodenum; a penetrating peptic ulcer on the posterior wall can erode into the gastroduodenal artery or one of its branches and cause haemorrhage.
  • A penetrating peptic ulcer on the anterior wall can perforate into the peritoneal cavity, causing peritonitis because the anterior surface of the superior part of the duodenum is covered only by the peritoneum.

choices.text: Coronary vein to right gastroepiploic vein
Inferior mesenteric vein to splenic vein
Left colic vein to middle colic vein
Splenic vein to left renal vein

questions.text: A surgeon needs to construct a bypass between the veins of the portal and caval systems to circumvent insufficient drainage through the natural portocaval anastomoses. Which plan is likely to be successful?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The splenic vein is a major vein of the portal system, while the left renal vein is a major vein of the renal system. These veins are large, so a bypass between them could be useful for relieving portal hypertension.

Porto-systemic anastomosis:

The obstruction of the portal vein leads to portal hypertension. Due to obstruction of blood in portal circulation is diverted to systemic circulation through post-systemic communications, because of which veins at such sites are dilated.

The coronary vein, right gastroepiploic vein, inferior mesenteric vein, splenic vein, left colic vein, middle colic vein, and superior mesenteric vein are all part of the portal system. Any bypasses among these veins will not relieve the portal hypertension.

questions.text: The inferior mesenteric vein typically drains into which vein?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The inferior mesenteric vein usually empties into the splenic vein, which is labelled as B in the above diagram.

Inferior mesenteric vein:

  • The inferior mesenteric vein drains the hindgut - the rectum and the sigmoid, descending and distal transverse colon.
  • It begins as the continuation of the superior anorectal vein from the rectal plexus and accompanies the superior rectal artery, crosses the pelvic brim and continues as the inferior mesenteric vein on the posterior abdominal wall.
  • It then lies to the left of the inferior mesenteric artery in the retroperitoneum and drains into the splenic vein.
  • Tributaries: Sigmoid veins and left colic vein.

The splenic vein and the superior mesenteric vein unite to form the portal vein behind the neck of the pancreas.
